splinternews.com  (WEB - en-US)

A staunchly liberal advocacy site on news, politics, and entertainment.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The site is owned by the Gizmodo Media Group, which also owns the youth-oriented websites Deadspin, Jezebel and LifeHacker. Gizmodo is a subsidiary of Univision Communications Inc., a publicly traded media company based in New York. The site runs clearly labeled ads, and derives revenue from its “Kinja Deals” product advertising section.

Content

Editor-in-Chief Aleksander Chan laid down his website’s editorial parameters in a July, 2018 mission statement: “We consider anyone standing in the way of beneficial material change for everyone to be an adversary—so, the obvious villains (millionaires, conservatives, the Trump administration), but also mealy-mouthed moderates, #resistance grifters, and publications providing cover for injustice by shrouding it in the false pretenses of ‘objectivity’ and ‘civility.’ “

Chan considers the world to be in crisis with a president who “has helped usher in an incomparably terrible time to be alive, online or otherwise; it’s impossible to effectively (or sufficiently) articulate the unyielding sense of dread that comes with experiencing the greatest moral crisis of a generation.”

It offers neutral news reporting and passionate advocacy. Republicans and President Trump head a list of frequent targets. Typical headlines include “Finally Senate Republicans Found a Judicial Nominee Who Was Too Racist Even For Them,” and  “House Republicans are Getting Their A***s Kicked in Fundraising.” But “neo liberals” and congress people such as Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer (in a post titled “Out with the Old”) are targets of the site’s disapproving posts as well.  

The often expletive-laced opinion pieces, some written in the first person, are not distinguished from news content, not labeled as commentary or opinion, or published in a separate section. For example, the news story “John McCain Dead at 81” ran in the same Congress menu as “John McCain’s Funeral Is Set To Be a Real Who’s Who of Bad Men and War Criminals.”

Most posts source original reporting by established news outlets, such as CNN, The New York Times and CBS, but the Splinter versions are written in stronger language that emphasizes the site’s left-leaning perspective. Many posts include videos, which are often retweets of material found on Twitter or from Splinter’s YouTube channel.

The site published the mobile phone number of White House adviser Stephen Miller in June of 2018. (“Here’s Stephen Miller’s Cell Phone Number, If You Need It.”) “Perhaps you would like to call him about it” [Trump administration immigration policy], the writer suggested. Many shares followed on Twitter and other social media. Since this was a violation of Twitter policy, Splinter’s Twitter account was temporarily suspended.

Three NewsGuard emails to Splinter editors about the lack of separation between opinion and news went unanswered. 

Credibility

The site lists contact information for reporters and top editorial staff. Biographies for writers are seldom provided, or reveal little. For example, the biography for Splinter News reporter Rafi Schwartz, reads “When in doubt, he’ll have the soup.” Ownership information is clear. Corrections are noted in a time-stamped, bold update at the bottom of the post in question, or, if editors consider the error to be serious, in the article’s headline.  

Transparency

The “About Splinter” page offers email and Twitter contacts for the entire staff, starting with editor-in-chief.

The “Kinja Deals” section works like an online catalogue. Products are showcased and surrounded with promotional, upbeat text along with links for users to buy the product. If a reader does make a purchase through a link, Splinter “may get a small share of the sale,” the site says. Readers can find a reference to “Kinja Deals” and disclosure of the cite’s affiliate marketing arrangement only by clicking on a tab called “Inventory,” on a horizontal bar at the top of Splinter News’s homepage.

History

The Splinter News website was created by Univision executives in July, 2017.  Univision had purchased the Gizmodo Media Group and added Splinter “to emphasize political and investigative reporting,” wrote Variety. The entertainment industry publication noted that such an editorial focus was “no surprise given the heightened public interest in the activities of the Trump administration.”
